job_title: Attractions Host/Hostess in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: - Range of experience is good. If you're looking to move up in parks/resorts attractions like this will benefit you more than thrill rides that seem fun to work - Hazard Pay is $1 more than other attractions - Unique work environment. No other park or zoo has an experience where, with no background, you could do this - For Animal Care / Conservation Educators this is a great stepping stone in your career. Former safari cast are now Managers, Coordinators in Education, and all over the AZA (Association of Zoos & Aquariums)
cons: - Huge team, nearly 300 cast members (employees). If theme parks are making you feel like a number not a value then this may not be the place where you shine - Becoming a trainer / a coordinator (like a team lead) doesn't pay much more for the added work

review_title: Consistent Employment, treatment by superiors not always the best.
pros: Good benefits (health, access to parks, resources for home and health, etc), easy to network, most positions are unionized, great place to make friends, and also a good job to do temporarily or long term. Looks good on your record/resume for other jobs. Gives good experience with customers and workplace procedures.
cons: Management not always reliable. It is very much a hit or miss. On one hand some managers are great and do as much as they can to help you when needed, on the other, some managers treat you poorly and are authoritarian. A lot of promotions are based on favoritism. You would have to make a lot of friends and network to move up. It is not always about work performance but the relationships you create with leaders and peers. The pay is not great. Majority of entry postitions don't pay a living wage. And even if you move up, the pay still could be better. You'd really have to move up to mid-senior positions to be making money.

review_title: It used to be a great place, but now it's a disaster
pros: The heart of the company is in the right place. They strongly believe in human rights, equality, volunteering, giving back. They attract mostly amazing people (there are some exceptions of course). I have always been proud to be associated with the Walt Disney Company.
cons: Disney reacts to the roller coaster of profitability in the extreme... by laying off its employees and quickly right-sizing their operating income on paper for their next meeting. Meanwhile, the workload is the same with only half the staff to do it. Everyone works on Sundays because they can't get their work done in five days. Employees are getting physically ill from it! To make up for the pandemic, we were told they were closing our campus and 2,000 employees were given the choice of moving to Orlando by Dec 2022 or losing their jobs. People SOLD their homes and moved, only to be told in June 2022 that the new campus won't be ready, so they'll be working from home for potentially YEARS. Turns out, they could have STAYED in California. This place is an absolute mess. I pray Bob Iger can bring the old Disney culture back, and treat their cast members like valuable assets, not disliked step-children.

pros: Working for the Walt Disney Company started feeling like it was a dream, I got to work for one of the biggest companies in the world and that thought alone made me feel like a rock star. My chefs and coworkers for the most part were fantastic. I enjoyed making the food on the cooking side of my time at the company and I enjoyed operating the rides on the attractions side of the company. I got to work many different locations including cooking at places like festivals and Biergarten at Epcot and Satuli Cantine at Animal Kingdom. The same goes for attractions, I operated the water slides in Blizzard Beach and Typhoon Lagoon as well as various rides in Hollywood Studios. These were some of the best parts of working at the company,
cons: Unfortunately the downsides to the Walt Disney Company were mental health related. At one point during my time working as a Cast Member operating in Hollywood studios I was suffering from crippling anxiety and depression and unfortunately I had talked to my leaders multiple times about it and there was nothing in their power they could do. This wasn't necessarily because they didn't want to help, but more due to the policies and guidelines of the company itself. the company's own policies kept my leaders from being able to help the way they needed or wanted to at the time causing me to have to resign.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Glendale, CA
pros: People are generally very nice to your face.
cons: TLDR: Probably cool if you're "a creative." Don't expect the royal treatment if you're anyone else. Terrible work/life balance. All of the remote-work advantages afforded by the pandemic are being taken away, forcing people to work in an office that isn't particularly nice by modern standards. Some of the technology teams, in particular, work in buildings that are barely equipped to be warehouses, let alone hold full-time staff. Work days are usually 9am - 7pm, so good luck visiting friends/family after work. Company also doesn't embrace summer Friday's (which, I know, is a huge perk at some places, how dare I ask for such a thing), so maintaining a social life can be difficult. Upward mobility is impossible. From my (limited) perspective, every manager rules their team with an iron fist, from the CEO down to the interns. Every employee lives in a box, and straying outside that box makes you seem like a rebel, which is looked down upon. From what I've seen, most of the best, most interesting, and most unique benefits that the company has to offer (free tuition, community volunteer work, tickets to parks, apparel, etc.) are largely performative and very few people are able to make legitimate use of them. Take, for example, the daycare center that Disney provides employees. Sounds like a great perk, but in reality is incredibly difficult to get your children into due to the competitive and very long waiting list. Disappointed overall that this company's words often don't match its actions. But hey, guess that's showbiz baby.

job_title: Food and Beverage Coordinator in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: The pros are always based on the employee experience from a perspective of the work you do and those who are alongside you [accomplishing their work or assisting you accomplish your own.]
cons: Regarding the comment from the pros section - the positive impact usually helps maintain a feeling of neutrality in the workplace, but any impactful negative contribution can have very lasting effects. This is more of a commentary on the peer-to-peer based work environment where a team is needed for the success of the individual. Particularly noticeable are the absent actions or negative contributions from the acting leadership team, whether it come from a place of inexperience, indecision, or rarely malice. The people in the operation will be the most defining aspect of your experience as an employee.

pros: - Great work-life balance after COVID-19, ironically. - Upper management that cares about your well-being. - Great team (at least in my division) that cares about each other, and capable to work seamlessly while remotely. It's as if we're on auto-pilot at times. - Decent salary, benefits, compensation, and reimbursement packages. - Great brand to represent. - During COVID-19 pandemic, you can work anywhere. - Sometimes you get chances to join Disney/Marvel/Star Wars titles pre-screening on cinemas.
cons: - Even after COVID-19, the bureaucracy is still going strong and rigid, as it's the main draw from corporate settings. - Promotions based on performance takes a long time to apply, to the point it's faster to get promoted if you quit the company, and rejoin 6 months or 1 year later. - Strategy changes could mean your position might be eliminated or moved somewhere else if the company needs it due to budget. - The change from SAP to Workday takes quite a long time. - Opportunities to move out to other division or other country is quite slim, unless you're not needed in your own division. - Due to the hybrid setting they are adopting now, it's almost impossible to work from anywhere, even though your job can be done from anywhere in the world.

review_title: House of Mouse has a few surprises
pros: Call me a pessimist, but when the pandemic hit, we didn't expect anything from the company. Those of us who were "weekly "qualified employees however, received pandemic assistance, which was an extremely fortunate thing for us, and not what we would have guessed. It's not untrue that this company sometimes does things on the cheap... For this reason, I'm giving Mickey a thumbs up for Doing the Right Thing.
cons: Same topic as the comment in the "Pros" category: The downside was that not everybody got the fantastic Pandemic Assistance. Let's say you worked at Disney for even a few hours shy of what would qualify you as a "weekly"employee (somewhere in the neighborhood of 1,000 to 1200 hours per calendar year... Don't quote me) Full disclosure, this experience is what was experienced at our location. And it's a pretty big, global company. And I know that, in general, contractual elements can play a roll regarding which company benefits any particular employee may or may not get. However, from where we saw it, it felt like the company "Did the Right Thing" for some of us, but not all of us--folks who worked just as hard as the weekly folk next to them--even in the very same job positions. And in a big majority of those cases, for us it was due to factors beyond our control: The amount of work offered. And as we all know, Coronavirus doesn't care whose lives are subsidized and whose lives are not. Made the non-weeklies feel like that in the eyes of the company, they weren't worth saving. I mean, think back to Spring 2020 until the vaccines were available -- it was a really stressful time, with a lot of fear and anxiety in the air. And anyone who told you they weren't scared of the virus? They were lying to themselves, at best. So there you have it.

review_title: Tough rewarding experience. Not worth the pay.
pros: Big enough to find work friends you work well with. Interacting with nice guests and talking about disney. Rotating around stores in the area. Obviously self admission and main entrance pass if its not blocked out or disappears during peak season due to “guests or business needs first”
cons: I’ve worked many different lands and it seems most managers have their hands tied with a million things and really do not care or have empathy for employees. There were only a few that cared to engage and actually reach out and help cast without cast begging. Getting a manager call back or answer is next to impossible which is hard when there is an urgent request or you are stuck at the gate with no id. Getting a decent consistent schedule is next to impossible even if you have been there several years. The company as a whole bribes cast with disguised tax write offs such as trinket name tag gifts, comp tickets, cast discounts, activities aka practice rounds of parades etc before it starts but nothing can replace being paid with more cash in our paycheck to pay bills. Moving up into the company is a tricky process and is often riddled with favoritism based on who interviewed you. One mistake such as a guest walking away with a bag before they finish paying results in you not being able to apply for full time for a whole year or applying for lead. One of many examples of things out of cast controls that prevents them from moving up and results in them being discouraged.

review_title: There is NO MAGIC except what YOU make.
pros: * Making Magic for families <3 * Free entrance and passes for family members to all parks. * Discounts at many Disney Springs stores.
cons: * Rock bottom pay for the areas cost of living. (mainly rent) * The company's Point System. (Ex. If you are late for work by a minute you will receive points on your permanent record.) After so many they call you in and treat you like a naughty child. (no matter your age or WHY the points are there) I cannot relay in words the unnecessary stress this will bring to your life. * Leaders (who walk a line between management and those of us that really run the show) will be very kind and "befriend you" until there is an issue. pros: Free tickets I guess if you consider waiting in lines on your day off to ride a roller coaster a perk.
cons: There is a reason everyone in central Florida HAS worked here. They thought oh it's going to be magic I want to work for Disney. Then they get a job after months because recruiting takes forever. They start their new job and guess what, it SUCKS. They quit and move on. Now, sure some people get brainwashed and sucked into the "magic" and work there forever until they die. How awful. There is no room for creativity at this company, it's the Disney way or no way. Alot of their ways don't make sense. Management favors employees, oops I mean Cast Members. Cast Members are union. My experience was awful. Depends on where you work, maybe you will have a good experience maybe you won't. You will also be majorly under compensated. Don't think the perks will make up for it, because they won't. I don't recommend, I'd recommend you never even think about working for this company. It's not worth it.

pros: The people! Good benefits. Good location. Interesting work. Innovative.
cons: Big, complex, can often take a long time to get approvals and move things forward. US driven, with often little understanding or consideration for other markets (at least that is how it feels). Not a con - but average pay. Hierarchical. Not easy to move up to the next level. Most departments are under-staffed. Tough getting headcount.

pros: You get into the parks for free Occasional dining discount You get overtime after 8hrs in a day
cons: Far more difficult work than what you get paid for. Whether you are apart of the union or not the raise is for everyone, but the company refuses to pay a livable wage. They set very hard to obtain standards and expect you to finish on time and take a lunch break. It’s a constant drama between the different ethnicities and also you take the time to clean and stock your cart at the end of the day but somehow every morning it is a mess from either PM shift or other AM housekeepers. The most management does on holidays like Christmas is some cocoa and muffins. It is an exhausting job that easily deserves $25/hr. Disney relies on low income low education immigrants to fill overworked and underpaid housekeeping positions. It is primarily Haitian and Latinos filling the spots. Management always say they appreciate us but nothing is ever done to make our roles easier, we are only given more work and more standards. We do not receive free meals despite working long hours and even on major holidays. It is a paycheck to paycheck job and you do not qualify for food assistance so most people are forced to be food insecure and rely on food left behind from guests. I know of other housekeepers personally that are dual income who cannot afford the cost of living in the state of FL without overtime. It is a very sad reality for the WDW housekeepers, it is not the happiest place on earth backstage. We do what we can to create magic but we are burnt out, and Disney do not care.

pros: The company wants you to feel like you matter. They make it a point to remind you that you’re doing the important work to uphold the company’s reputation and the people you address your concerns with want to make you feel like you’re being heard and understood. Your workplace is usually very diverse with all sorts of people from a variety of backgrounds to learn from and get to know, and there is no shortage of interesting and exciting stories to share with one another.
cons: Bureaucratic nightmare. Every conversation that you have with leadership is surface level at best and at worst will be used against you should the powers that be deem it necessary to take disciplinary action. Union representation is slow and disorganized, and asking the same question to multiple union reps could return a different answer. Leaders will take your ideas and claim them as their own without a shred of remorse or shame. Inconsistent enforcement of certain policies reflects an obvious playing of favorites in certain situations. Trying to “climb the ladder” is a popularity contest. It doesn’t matter how good you are at your job, you’re only as successful as you are liked. Benefits and compensation are mediocre when compared to the working conditions in certain roles—some of the most physically demanding jobs are paid the same or less than more “cushy” ones. The attendance policy treats being sick effectively the same as wanting to take a day off to hang out with friends, and there is often little flexibility when emergencies arise.

pros: As a performer for Disney, I have had the opportunity to work on some truly magical productions. The attention to detail and dedication to creating unforgettable experiences for audience members is unmatched in the industry. I have been constantly impressed by the level of talent and professionalism of my fellow cast and crew members, as well as the support and guidance provided by the company. One of the highlights of working for Disney is the opportunity to bring beloved characters to life. Whether it's dancing as a princess, singing as a pirate, or acting as a classic Disney sidekick, each role is a thrilling challenge and a chance to make lasting memories for both myself and the audience. In addition to the creative opportunities, Disney also provides its performers with top-notch training and support. From vocal coaching and dance rehearsals to character development workshops and rehearsals, the company ensures that its performers are always at the top of their game. Overall, I am incredibly grateful for my time as a performer for Disney and feel fortunate to have been a part of such a talented and dedicated team. I would highly recommend working for the company to any performer looking to be part of something truly special.
cons: It is difficult to think of any significant negatives when it comes to working for Disney as a performer. However, one potential con could be the demanding schedule and long hours that come with the job. Performing in live shows and productions can require a lot of time and energy, and some performers may find the schedule to be challenging to balance with their personal lives. Additionally, working in the entertainment industry can be unpredictable, and there is always the possibility of unexpected changes or challenges arising. Performers may need to be adaptable and ready to roll with the punches in order to succeed in this field. Overall, while there may be some challenges and demands associated with working for Disney as a performer, the rewards and opportunities offered by the company far outweigh any potential drawbacks.

review_title: Streaming side of the business is an amazing place to be an engineer
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Boston, MA
pros:
* working on a product many people use at a company many people have very positive feelings for
* extremely technical engineering managers (even at the director and VP levels)
* interesting challenges to solve
* (mostly) good tech stack choices
* manageable deadlines resulting in a good work/life balance
* plenty of avenues for advancement, including moving to other parts of Disney (though for software engineers and similar see also cons below)
* unique perks not found at many other companies such as free park admission and a shopdisney discount
* leadership that genuinely cares about delivering high quality products
* decent (though not great) pay
cons:
Pay isn't as high compared to many other companies, and while it's not terrible by any means, this probably isn't a great place for people looking for more competitive compensation.

Software engineering within Disney Streaming is amazing, but other parts of Disney, especially parks, are entirely different and probably best avoided for people working in tech.

review_title: Lots of technology and tons of meetings
pros: From an IT network perspective Disney is like many other similar sized companies in that there is tons of infrastructure with plenty of things to work on. Some of configurations are complex enough to really make you think on how to move something forward. I felt that there were some very talented people that you had a chance to learn from when they were willing and able to train you.
cons: The one thing that is frustrating is that there was pretty poor onboarding. I genuinely didn't get much training in my role for weeks on end. I got scheduled plenty of meetings that were something relevant to my role, but often not so relevant. The amount of meetings some days was crazy. e.g. 4-5 hours of meetings was pretty normal and sometimes more. When 50% or more of your day is covered by meetings it is surprising we got much done. Relative to many tech companies the pay seems less competitive. In addition, it felt like plans for changes were sometimes haphazard and you deal with multiple different contracting agencies that manage different parts of the network so a ticket might go through multiple different layers before it gets to the right person.

review_title: No progression opportunities and toxic/old school environment
pros:
Great brands/IP to work with
Lovely people
Health insurance and discount at store
Good for entry level - lots of people to meet, get stuck in (as even interns have so so much responsibility due to lack of staff)
cons:
There is no progression unless someone leaves, salary also doesn't properly get reviewed, just an annual 1-3% rise (hardly in line with inflation)
When you ask about salary bands, you are never given one - often told you are at the top end of your bracket only to hear someone else is earning much more (or sadly much less for the same title)
Mental health is spoken about a lot but workloads are high, hours are long and a mental health first aider isn't enough to tackle this - when the team asks for more resource, it's never granted.
Environment can be quite toxic depending on team, praise is rarely given but you'll know if you make a mistake. Everyone is lovely but exhausted and team morale is low.
Lots of red tape (due to large company), it takes a long time to get something approved so things move slowly, information is also communicated down the chain very slowly.

pros: Paid well compared to other customer service call center positions. You will also have the opportunity to move around in the call center or even up within 3-6 months of employment. This will depend on which department you started with and which one you’re moving to. Disney also has a Cast Center on-site to assist with any career growth questions you may have that your leader may not know.
cons: You will be expected to handle a wide array of tasks that used to be split into multiple departments but has since been merged into one. You will have required overtime for most of the year. You are given 56 hours of “call out time” each year and the rest of your vacation days will be accrued throughout the year versus other companies offering a set amount of time off that you would use as you wish. Shift bids favor senior tenure with the company so the longer you’ve worked for Disney, the better your work schedule could be. This also means you could be working late nights with no weekends off for awhile depending on your community. The call center is also open 365 days a year so you will more than likely be working holidays but will have the opportunity to bid to have them off each winter.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Burbank, CA
pros: Good HR policy overall, relatively inclusive environment, pretty decent benefits.
cons: Out of touch management. Disney's weak link is it' senior leadership. This is a company that has done many re-organizations, hired many consultants and made several other attempts to transform the organization. But transformation stops at middle management. We see the same old tired and under qualified leaders taking over major portions of Disney. This leads to a management that talks the talk but does not walk the walk. They celebrate work anniversaries but fire talented engineers in droves for no other reason than the product they have worked on for the last several years is being replaced by a commoditized offering. They make it orders of magnitude harder for employees to find other work within the org than they do for outside people to come in at higher levels. If your career velocity is low then Disney is the place for you. You might also be happy in a government job. If you want to be challenged and grow then Disney should be seen as a short term stepping stone to bigger and better things.

Being able to work with other tech nerds that love all things Disney: Star Wars and Marvel Cinematic Universe to just name two. Access to free or reduced priced experiences including park access and Disney cruises. Free movies on occasion. Lots of emphasis on skilling up inside the company with access to training, classes, mentoring, and more. Super white-glove support from vendors (think of all the big cloud and SW vendors, basically) since they value DIS as a customer and want to keep support and satisfaction levels high. Great work-life balance. In "Compensations & Benefits
", my high score is strictly for the benefits...not so much for comp.
cons: Pay is lower than what other, comparable positions are making in other big-tech companies like Amazon, Microsoft, Google, Apple, etc. DIS tries to compete for the same candidates but offers lower salaries because of the hype around the perks and the fact that DIS is not a tech-first company (IMHO).

pros:
Non hostile management. Seriously, not having a single leader jump down anyone's throat is a rarity in F&B.
Good pay per hour. I have worked less and made more, but the pay has mostly been good.
The points system means if you really need to call out you won't lose your job. It also means sometimes you come to work and you are alone. Leadership really works hard to call everyone and get coverage. The more respectful employees reach out and try to get a shift covered.
cons: Service bartenders are not guaranteed to get more than the $7 per hour WDW pays you. They don't ensure you make consistent or fair service pay. They could have added a service charge for drinks. The server/bartender union only looks out for servers and full time bartenders, part timers get no representation. The union could have required a minimum percentage from servers, but instead some nights you could make 200 drinks for a restaurant and make $100, or ignore the service well and wait on 10 bar guests and make the exact same amount. If they want service to get better, ensure that we make enough (or any) money for service well drinks. T.I.P.S.-to ensure prompt service.

pros:
For the Record: this is going to be Company specific and not Position specific. I spent 13 years working for the Disneyland Resort and alot has changed from when I started until now. 

Pros: Superb benefits - health, dental, medical benefits are great. Complementary park admission is fantastic. Discounts were great. I was afforded the opportunity to work for various lines of businesses (LOBs) and under different managers. I met some of my best friends and incredible mentors during this time. You are introduced to a wonderful, ever evolving group of people, and you find yourself stretched and pushed to your limits (in a good way!)
cons:
Social Cons - obviously it is a company with a very specific echo chamber of beliefs. If you stray even the slightest you will feel the social repercussions of this. For me, it felt like I was overlooked for many promotions and considering I had a great record, guest compliments, and peer references, I had to wonder why that was. I left the company after being furloughed for over a year, so I did not have to experience the full manifestation of social change (for the worse) that many current cast members have experienced but I can tell you that I probably would have been isolated had I gone back. For a company that promotes Diversity and Inclusion, they are very specific with who that includes. 

Professional Cons - what felt like endless room for opportunity became a barren wasteland towards the end of my career. I had reached out to management multiple times for new opportunities and responsibilities and I was either pushed towards the Management program or told to stay in my lane. I know there is so much more than just being a manager at the Disneyland resort (for me, I do not want to take on a leadership role) but I was never recommended for anything. 

Academic Cons - The new Aspire program was sold as an opportunity to have your education paid for (100%) by the company. I earned my Bachelors earlier in my Disney career, so I opted for the Masters program. I started as one of the first groups to go through Aspire in 2019. I worked throughout the pandemic 2020/2021 and finished in March 2021. During this time, I was furloughed (previously mentioned) and receiving unemployment from the State of California. The Walt Disney Company told the State of California that I was receiving a salary during my furlough ( I was not, I was having my education paid for) and although it showed up on my paystubs (not as income but as education credit) the State of California is accusing me of Unemployment Fraud. When I reached out various times to the The Walt Disney Company Human Resources they refused to assist me, or clear my name.

Left after less than a year because of how chaotic it was. Management and seniors feel very high up and unreachable. Huge hierarchy and red tape around everything makes it difficult to feel like a part of the company. Barely any room for progression due to how overworked each person is, which is not helped by how the processes for everything are messy. Very US-centere meaning no strategy, planning, and decisions are being made even in the London EMEA office. Not to mention pay is not only below industry standard but also just general workload standard. Highly political and beurocratic. 

Find somewhere else. There is no magic in corporate disney.

review_title: Can't Rave Enough About This Position!
pros: Seriously the coolest position you'll ever have in the parks. So much fun hanging with characters all day. Co-workers are the best around and seriously the funniest people. You get to work all over both parks and hotels which makes for a nice change of scenery and you're never bored. You wont have any problems getting full time hours as a part time worker if you need the money. You get the same amount of benefits as other part time employees do with your free swipe ins, comp tickets, and discounts on merch and food.
cons: If you have high anxiety, aren't okay with loud noises, aren't good with large crowds, or aren't good with yelling or speaking loudly in front of crowds it is probably not the right position for you. Schedules are all over the place until you have seniority. You have to be comfortable working both indoors and outdoors since characters meet in both settings. Need to be great at following spreadsheets and schedules because that's a huge part of the job that you're responsible for.

pros:
Free park tickets 
Private healthcare & dental
The people that you work with are genuinely nice
cons:
Where to start… there’s no clear career progression and pay rises are a joke (1-3%) even after being told that you'll be "looked after". Added insult especially during a cost of living crisis. 

You’ll be expected to work above your contracted hours due to the workload and the fact that they don't hire enough workers on the ground. Instead it’s very top heavy with management. A lot of decisions are made last minute which creates massive amounts of churn, especially as a lot of decisions will either filter from the US or will have to be approved by them (adding at least 1-2 days of turnaround time).

They use the right mental health buzzwords but nothing is really taken seriously, employees are just pointed towards the EAP. Little-to-no support was given during the reintroduction to the office which, in itself, was a farce being forced to go back in on 3 FIXED days per week which they called “flexible”. It was called a test and learn phase and we were surveyed but no changes were implemented based on employee feedback. 

The office lacks any sense of character and feels more like a consultancy with bright white lights and no chill-out spaces. They have a clean-desk policy which means you can't bring any personality to your own space. 

Everyone you work with is lovely but everyone's under constant stress so there's no real culture or feeling of being a wider team. The socials that happen once in a blue moon are fun but few-and-far between. 

Finally, processes are constantly changing and hurdles are moved so you’ll get all of the cons of a start-up and a corporate all in once place.

review_title: Good but Have to Know What You’re Signing Up For
pros: Interacting with guests and making kids greatest day of their life is extremely fulfilling. Having grown up loving the Disney rides and then now operating them, is satisfying knowing the experiences you’re bringing to others.
cons: It’s not for everyone, and your experience is going to be based first and foremost upon which attraction you’re operating. Some are more simple, others are complicated-stress-inducing monsters. I operated 5 very different attractions during my time, and I can tell you I loved operating Astro Orbiter WAY more than Mine Train. Why? Safety, logistics, crowds, control, show, accountability/liability. Those are all elements of different attractions and each attraction hosts them very differently. This isn’t just a job, you’re in charge of people’s and children’s safety. If you do one wrong thing even on accident, you can get safety reprimanded, permanent marks on your record, and terminated. All it takes is one brat kid and careless parents to act dumb under your watch while you’re trying to be vigilant. This is more possible in certain attractions than others. Be careful. Beyond this, you must be adept to repetitive motions, instruction-giving, and sounds playing. Again, some attractions are less demanding of others. Yes, you will make the day of many young kids and families, and see their eyes light up…but realize it’s also at the cost of dealing with every frustrating type of human know to mankind.

review_title: Not the same Company from when I started a decade ago.
job_title: Attractions Host in Bay Lake, Optional[FL]
pros: Getting hired is easy enough. You'll have plenty of hours if you need them (you have the flexibility to trade shifts, and pick up hours ). Sometimes taking time off can be difficult. Full-time cast members have access to health insurance, dental, vision, company-paid for life insurance, credit monitoring, and completely free tuition assistance.
cons: The biggest con right now is Chapek. Management has steadily gone downhill over the years. The focus is no longer on creating magical experiences for the Guests, rather on efficiency (how many people you can get in and out every hour). Guests feel like they are herded like cattle and they (justly) complain that they are being nickled-and-dimed. There is a strong sense of low morale among cast members throughout the parks. There is also a growing disconnect between frontline workers and management (and executives). There is high turnaround in attractions, and this could also mean forced overtime since staffing is tight. If Disney keeps their current ways it will soon begin to alienate its employees and Guests.

review_title: Big Company is what it is
pros: Being a big company means lots of events, benefits, programs, and diversity. There are lots of jobs available. Company will pay your full school tuition with no strings attached.
cons: Being big also means you feel like just a number. It is often hard to break into management opportunities despite company loyalty. With so many people, hourly roles are not competitively priced and are often far below the average needed to live a modest life in the area, even roles with high skill levels required. Upper management only acts like they care about that, but they don't. Break spaces are often awful. Not a lot of support for working parents until you're in a salaried position.

pros:
I have been with the company for almost five years now and I have enjoyed almost every bit of it. Support Lead keeps me busy as I am in the office most of the time filing audits, checking Working Lead Paperwork, Assisting with scheduling labor etc. I'm never bored, so I enjoy it very much.
I also get the chance to be in the location helping out where I can with the roles that I know, hence why we are "supports" because we support the location where and when needed.
cons: At least for the location I am at, I find myself having to leave the office frequently because we don't have our own space, as we share with the managers.
